p: In the United States (US), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has estimated that influenza has caused between 9.3 and 49.0 million illnesses each year, since 2010- along with between 12,000 and 79,000 deaths annually [ 1]. Two types of influenza cause seasonal, global epidemics in human populations each year: influenza A virus (IAV) and influenza B virus (IBV) [ 2, 3]. IAVs can also cause sporadic pandemics of great consequences when new viruses are introduced into humans [ 4].
